The power of Boolean formulas has been intensively investigated since the early years of complexity theory (see, e.g.,Â        7 ). The techniques underlying these complexity-theoretic results have also enabled algorithmic developments. These include learning algorithms 1 4, satisfiability algorithms (cf.Â 8), compression algorithms , and the construction of pseudorandom generators  for Boolean formulas of different sizes. But despite many decades of research, the current non-trivial algorithms and lower bounds apply only to formulas of less than cubic size, and understanding larger formulas remains a major open problem in circuit complexity. In many scenarios, however, understanding smaller formulas whose leaves are replaced by certain functions would also be very useful.
